comments.commentBody:
To continue a failing presidential campaign in order to get publicity for some future enterprise in broadcasting deserves the expressed disgust of every politician, Republican and Democrat. This makes a mockery of an election. These are serious traditions and quintessential elements of our democracy, being misused so as to get more attention through outrageous behavior. Trump's son-in-law's feelers regarding Trump's media plans say it all.

But will the Republican's call him out on it? Nope. They have to toady to Fox's new replacement. They may be bitterly criticized come the next primary. America, we've been suckered!

The Trump campaign has been such a fiasco that it is tempting to suppose that it is an aberration, like that of third-party campaigns -- e.g. George Wallace or Ross Perot -- and that once it's over, things will return to normal.    But who will drive those Trumpite voters -- angry white people all over this country, whom you might call Tea Party II  -- back into their cave?   No one will.  On the contrary, other wild candidates after Trump will try to rouse them again in four years, or even less in state races.   For the moment, they have taken over the Republican Party: it is as if the Republican presidential field had been "primaried" -- attacked and overthrown from the right.   If they believe they have been cheated out of victory this year, the Trumpites might be even angrier and motivated for next time.   As for the GOP overall, I think of a hungry snake that has swallowed a large heavy mammal, but must lie there until the great morsel has been digested, or excreted.

In so many posts in the comments section during this election season, I have read that DJT doesn't really want to be president.  This could not be further from the truth.  I'll concede that he may not want to do the work of the presidency, but he desperately wants -- needs -- all the rest; the balls and galas, the military standing at attention when he walks by, the playing of Hail to the Chief when he enters the room, the standing ovations and applause, the cameras, receiving and visiting foreign dignitaries, even his face carved into Mt. Rushmore.  That's his principle desire and if he does not win this contest, he will consider it to have been the greatest tragedy of his life.

I know that logic is not one of Donald Trump's strengths but he seems unable to get his ridiculous act together.

He said today in Ohio "I will totally accept elections results if I win", presumably meaning that there is a chance that elections won't be rigged.

But yesterday, during the debate, he said that the elections are rigged.

So Mr. Trump, what is it, are the elections rigged or not rigged?

If the elections are already rigged, as he claimed during the debate, there is no need to clarify that he will accept the results because he is going to lose given the fact that they are rigged.

But, if he still can win, as he said in Ohio, then the elections are not rigged as he claimed during the debate.

A more principled, if crazy, stance, would be for Mr. Trump to claim just that the elections are rigged.

We, of course, know what all this means in the unfathomable meanders of his sinister mind: Elections are rigged if I lose, but they aren't if I win.

I look forward to Nov. 9 to get this annoying and dangerous character out of the way.

I have one serious question on the voter fraud/ rigged issue.
Trump says it is possible, but ALL of the MSM commentary says that is ridiculous, studies show otherwise, could happen locally but never in a national election.
Have they all forgotten that the 2000 election for president actually came down to 500 votes???

replies.commentBody: 2015 Hillary and the DNC rig the election against Bernie Sanders DNC chair women resigns .  2016 Hillary and the DNC hey protesters and thugs to provoke violence at Trump rally's to D&C employees resign .  Discuss

comments.commentBody:
2008. Barack Obama - an African American - runs for President. The GOP begins its offensive and corrupt strategies.

2016. Hillary Clinton - a woman - runs for President. The GOP continues its deplorable and offensive strategies.

Discuss.

"Now through a glass darkly" Donald Trump sees the world conspiring against him. He conducts his affairs maintaining an upper hand using insults and threats of lawsuits, and cuts down anyone who disputes his reasoning. Now that it's clear that his candidacy is probably in free-fall, Trump cannot take responsibility for his own reckless behavior.

When Barack Obama was elected President, the rhetoric was so vitriolic I feared for his life.

I had no idea what was coming in this election cycle.

My fear for HRC totally eclipses that which came before.

The Republicans that claim that Trump doesn't represent what Republican voters think should check out today's Bloomberg poll.  When asked who represents their view of the party, Republican voters said 51 percent Trump to 33 percent Ryan.

Keep in mind the South Carolina Representative Wilson who shouted "you lie" to the President of the United States of America at the 2009 State of the Union. That's where it started to become evident to the world what the GOP had in store for the country.
The GOP dug its own grave.

replies.commentBody:
Right. There's absolutely no difference between Trump saying that he won't accept any results that have HRC winning, together with his making up voter fraud issues and encouraging his followers to intimidate minority voters and Liberal frustration that in a race where the winning margin was razor thin, the conservative Supreme Court prematurely stopped the recount in Florida to ensue that Bush won.

Yep. No difference whatsoever there.

comments.commentBody: All this contrived outrage is nothing if not amusing.  Anyone remember the line that Bush stole the election?  It is still prevalent today.  I guess some just revel in their hypocrisy.

Even if nothing else good comes out of Trump at least one thing we would have learnt: "Truth is not made of mere words, whoever may be speaking them. Your truth has its foundation in belief and your belief comes out of your knowledge which is acquired by your own observations and learning". To save time & energy, modern trend is to go for predigested "knowledge" which is also known as "media" and adopt it as "truth". Naturally it differs from person to person depending which "media" is shaping his "Truth". Nation should be thankful to Trump for the bitter lesson.

Debate Stunner?
Not really. It would have been more surprising if Trump upheld
the tradition of grace after loss and support of the election process.
I have an Aunt who suffers from lifelong narcissism. It's one of the toughest of the Personality Disorders to address. From my experience it's those at the receiving end of self aggrandizing rants who have a greater chance of being healed from the pain and damage flung at them. We should all be seeking help at this point.

The narcissist goes to their grave believing they are better, smarter, and even nicer than anyone else etc.

America's best bet is walking away from Narcissist Trump at the polls. For Trump's heirs you've got some waiting to do.
What's worse are the fools that thinks this guy is viable..

replies.commentBody: Well, if we know this election is rigged, then I fail to see the need to have an election at all.   If the only possible legitimate outcome would be for Donald Trump to win, why don't we just award him the presidency right now?

comments.commentBody:
Hillary's campaign is quickly firing and trying to distance themselves from the Democrat crooks caught on film boasting about how they rig elections and perform other dirty tricks like paying people to cause disturbances at Trump rallies.

The crook team leader, whose name is not worth remembering, visited the Obama White House HUNDREDS of times. He met with the President himself DOZENS of times.

It truly is a shame that we have to worry that elections are rigged.

The Democrats try to blame the Russians. The Russians are blamed, not for rigging the elections, but for exposing the Democrats actively rigging elections, which is somehow unfair to the Democrats because they like to rig elections in private.

replies.commentBody:
In addition, there is ZERO evidence -- ZERO -- that he would put in the work required, even at a bare minimum, to do the job of President. He is either being incredibly disingenuous, or spectacularly unaware in his belief that he can't just be "chief deligator".

This is one of the hardest, if not THE hardest, jobs on the planet, and he's just not up to the task at hand.

"Thanks for coming in and interviewing. We'll let you know ( * eye roll * ) -- Buh-bye."
'Heads I win, tails you lose', says Trump!

comments.commentBody:
Is anyone trying to get at the truth of what this man is doing? He clearly doesn't care about bettering the country, and never has. He doesn't care what he says, or does, as long as it brings him and his brand attention. I don't believe he ever wanted to be president, he certainly didn't think he would get THIS far.

He probably doesn't even want to become president, because he knows he wouldn't be able to function, and he's really just not bright enough to handle it.
It's all a joke to him.

Americans and American corporations should boycott all of his products and properties and prove that what a person says and does in public, as well as in private, has consequences.

“I will totally accept the results of this great and historic presidential election — if I win,” -- These are the words of a seventh grader. IT'S ALL A JOKE TO HIM, HE DOESN'T CARE.

replies.commentBody: Poster boy for mental health funding.

comments.commentBody: Trump's doubling down on lunacy statements, as he already gave up on the election and is just building his brand for Trump Channel's target market, post Nov. 8

replies.commentBody: You should add most of the institutes of higher learning in the United States as part of the entrenched élite.  The extortionate and totally unjustifiable tuition rates which they impose upon the masses are responsible for the forced pauperisation of millions of Americans leading existences akin to the indentured servants who were shipped to colonial America against their will.  Unfortunately, American society still views a university education as an optional frill, a delusion which runs counter to the higher expectations of employers in every field.  This contradiction in values is exemplified by the lack of will on the part of the élite to allow all eligible and motivated citizens access to a decent higher education without having to start out in life with the equivalent debtload of a house.... before even setting up house!
Instead of elite I think you meant educated.

"If the elite continue to ignore this rage, it will be not just at their own peril, but that of the republic."

Fidel Castro, or someone like him should run. Now, there's a "man of the people".

comments.commentBody:
My guess, from looking at the polling numbers, is that at least 40% of U.S. citizens view the political, business and media elite as illegitimate.

Unless that elite - including the folks at MSNBC, FOX, WaPo, the NYTs, etc; Citbank, Goldman Sachs, Apple, etc; and all of Washington - wake up and smell the coffee, that number will grow to 60%, 705 or more, and a more effective leader will likely emerge.

If the elite continue to ignore this rage, it will be not just at their own peril, but that of the republic.

Here are the party affiliations for the secretaries of state who certify elections in each of the eight "battleground" states. Fifty percent are Republicans so looks like the GOP is conspiring to steal the election from Mr. Trump if we take seriously his comments about a rigged process. Restores my faith in the GOP.
New Hampshire William Gardner Democrat
Pennsylvania Pedro Cortes Democrat
N Carolina Elaine Marshall Democrat
Wisconsin Doug La Follette Democrat
Ohio John Hustad Republican
Florida Ken Detzner Republican
Colorado Wayne Williams Republican
Nevada Barbara Cegavska Republican

replies.commentBody:
"Confronting Trump with the truth is wasted time. He lies with a purpose - he learned this lesson from the past."

Trump tells the "Chateau Lafite Rothschild, '57 vintage" of lies. He's a true connoisseur.

comments.commentBody: Confronting Trump with the truth is wasted time. He lies with a purpose - he learned this lesson from the past. During his campaign, President Reagan repeatedly described a  "welfare queen" (as he put it) who presumably used 80 names, 21 social security cards, numerous food stamps and drove a Cadillac. Truth was that such a woman never existed but he ran with it. Likewise, Trump makes up stories as he goes and hope he can win a landslide. Except he is not running against President Carter.

This has been an awful election.  Still like most I've been following it closely.  Apart from the unbelievable rhetoric, another thing I find appalling is how Donald dominates the news every day for months.  Never mind Syrian refugees, Matthew in Haiti, Aleppo. . . The world stops to listen to the ramblings of a madman while truly matters of consequence barely make the news.  Public Good!!!  That's what government is for - not to satisfy egos of narcissists.

replies.commentBody: There is no "Syria" anymore. Russian troops are supporting Assad who has never been elected, has no legitimate claim on power, and is simply one side in the ongoing civil war. The US has taken the opposite side - and why not? So if a Russian plane foolishly strays where it's not welcome, it'll be shot down. When you get involved in a war, prepare for casualties. I hope President Clinton will be able to curb Putin's aggression in Ukraine (talking about forgotten wars!) and clip his wings in the Middle East.

comments.commentBody: And re: the debate: there was only one question Wallace asked last night that he didn't press the answer for when the candidate evaded: no surprise, it was when he asked Clinton whether she would shoot down a Russian plane if it entered a US-imposed no-fly-zone in Syria. The hacks in the media desperately want us to think Russia's the aggressor in the world -- Russia, invited into Syria, yet the US under Clinton would shoot down a Russian plane flying in Syrian airspace. Small wonder Wallace didn't press it.

I'm glad Hillary Clinton clarified last night that she doesn't think wealthy people should get the same shake from the Justices on the Supreme Court.

I'm also glad that John Podesta clarified this week that they are setting up organizations with Catholic sounding names in order to subvert the Church and undermine their entire order.

See? This is what transparency does. It shines the light where it normally wouldn't.

replies.commentBody: I agree. He must be gotten off the front pages. That's exactly what he wants..to be the center of attention.

"Should Donald Trump lose the election on November 8, could the media entities that gave him the power to become the candidate agree that there is no more story?"

Sure, but ONLY after his fragile ego suffers as much humiliation and degradation as is necessary to counter-balance the pain, suffering and embarrassment that he put the country through. That, unfortunately, could take eons.

/ sarcasm off*

(* for those that thought I was kidding)

comments.commentBody: Should Donald Trump lose the election on November 8, could the media entities that gave him the power to become the candidate agree that there is no more story? It's going to be years of work to return to civility and decency in public discourse in America if we ever get there. Could we just agree that if he does lose, America will not be subjected to endless interviews with and profiles of the failed candidate?

replies.commentBody:
"The Republican Party like the Liberal Party in Canada, believe that they have a divine right to power. Donald Trump just raise that believe to a new level. By the way Nixon in his Memoirs complained about fraud of the Democratic Party in Texas and Illinois, but contrary to Donald Trump, he putted the country first and recognized the legitimacy of the 1960 Presidential Election."

I'm a card carrying member of the Liberal party of Canada, and I've always putted the country first.

comments.commentBody: The Republican Party like the Liberal Party in Canada, believe that they have a divine right to power. Donald Trump just raise that believe to a new level. By the way Nixon in his Memoirs complained about fraud of the Democratic Party in Texas and Illinois, but contrary to Donald Trump, he putted the country first and recognized the legitimacy of the 1960 Presidential Election.
